What if it actually is that good? You know? You may just have to read it. INT. We find Sarah on the couch reading the current bestseller, Primary Colors and Lipsky beside her reading Infinite Jest. Silence.
Shit.
Buzzing with the hip, youthful industry of people who kno they’re at the place to be. Lipsky drops by to see his editor, BOB LEVIN, 40, greying, bearded.
How many times have we interviewed a writer in the last ten years? Guess.
Um... how many?
Zero. I checked.
Maybe that’s because Rolling Stone doesn’t interview writers.
There hasn't been a writer like this one. Once in a generation, maybe. Hemingway, Pynchon. Let me have this story.
What story?
18 20 21 Lipsky tosses Newsweek, opened to a photo of Wallace, ont Bob’s messy desk.
He’s finishing up his book tour and I want to go with him.
That’s not a story.
He teaches at some small state university, somewhere in Illinois. Send me there. Please, Bob. This is the sort of stuff I should be doing, not 500-words on boy bands. Talk to Jann?
Lipsky works at his computer. Newsweek with the Wallace photo lands on his desk. Lipsky looks up and sees Bob.
There had better be a story there... Bob leaves.
(calls) There will be! His smile fades. Now what?

Sarah reads her own copy of Infinite Jest as Lipsky walks back and forth across frame, gathering stuff to pack for trip. Laptop. Notebook. Wallace's books, full of notation and post-its. Tape recorder, packs of audio cassettes. He considers then tosses in The Art Fair and zips up his bag
A grey wintry morning. Lipsky, outside his building, hail taxi.
Lipsky, in the backseat, reads Infinite Jest; he’s about three-quarters of the way through it. He makes a note in margin, then glances out the window at the passing skylin  22 25 26 27
An American Airlines plane comes in for a landing on the flat, grey, wintry landscape.
Lipsky, on the road, drives past a sign for Bloomington.

An American landscape of fast-food places and chain store Lipsky’s Grand Am is parked in a 7-Eleven and Citco stati He stands at a pay phone. (We never intercut during telephone conversations.) DAVID’S VOICE (over phone) Hello?
David, hi, it’s David Lipsky. DAVID’S VOICE Where are you?
I think I may have made a wrong turn somewhere. Let’s see, I’m on County Highway 29, across from Circus Video? DAVID’S VOICE How'd you get this number?
Your publicist sent it in her e-mail, just in case. DAVID’S VOICE You'd do me a favor by losing it.

Stormy skies. Flat, wintry terrain. As the car pulls up, Lipsky sees, through the windshield, a modest, one-story brick house in the distance, and a man emerging from it. From Lipsky’s long shot POV: DAVID FOSTER WALLACE, hands shoved in his jeans pockets for warmth, accompanied by hi two barking, rambunctious black labs, JEEVES and DRONE. Lipsky parks. He takes a deep, bracing breath before gett out of the car to finally meet the man about whom he has complicated feelings. He walks toward him. This is the first time we see David up close and in focu stubble, long hair, blue bandanna, wire-rims, Frye boots, 6'2” and, at this time in his life, burly.
You made it.

Yeah. Hi. David offers his wary, tolerant hand. This being the end his tour, his patience is frayed and he’s just about talk out. But, at the same time, it’s Rolling Stone, he wants make a good impression.
Dave. Dave Wallace.

David Lipsky. Pleasure. Lipsky is cowed but determined to hold his own. These are two really smart, competitive guys out to impress each ot Wallace wants to be favorably profiled and Lipsky wants Wallace’s approval - and a good story.
Sorry about the phone call.
95% joke. Lipsky laughs.
Sorry in advance about the dogs, gonna be slobbering all over you.
Oh, I don’t mind. I love dogs.
Yeah? Well, you haven’t met these guys... It’s cold, let’s go inside. (to the dogs) Jeeves, Drone! Get over here! Lipsky follows David and the rowdy, barking dogs into the house.  28 10.
Lipsky drops his bag on the messy, shit-stained shag carp The dogs are indeed all over him. Lipsky scratches their heads and speaks to them as a dog lover would speak to do
Yes, I’m very glad to meet you, too. Who are you?
That’s Jeeves. The Jeevesmeister. I got him ‘cause he was so ugly. No one else wanted him. Now he’s like a Cover Girl-dog. Aren't you, Jeeves? Yes, you are. And this is Drone. My provisional dog.
Why provisional?
Just showed up one day while Jeeves and I were out jogging and the rest is history. (A beat.) I feel like I should offer you tea or something.

Yeah. Thanks. That would be great. David goes to put on water. We STAY on Lipsky, casually studying the room with the eye of a journalist, taking in grad-student-like accoutrements: cramped cinder-block bookshelves; hodgepodge of furniture, an ALANIS MORISSETT POSTER conspicuously on the wall. Lipsky, glancing out th window at the wintry landscape, raises his voice to conve with David, who’s in the kitchen.
Nice view.
Thank you. I can’t take credit for it. Lipsky smiles. Pause.
So... Have you always been unlisted?
(from the kitchen) I had to do that recently. It was getting crazy.
Because of fans?
I don’t know if “fan” would be the right word... I think what happened was, I had forgotten to tell my parents not to give my number out. So it was people who tracked my parents down, and um -
(knowing) Ohhh.
I have this terrible problem, I just really hate to hurt people’s feelings. So I did something kinda cowardly.
Unlisting your number’s not cowardly.

It kinda is. I mean, I changed my number so these folks couldn’t find me anymore. There was this computer operator in Vancouver, lived in a basement. Who I found really moving. In terrible terrible pain.
What did he want from you?
Wasn’t clear, and when I would sort of ask him, he’d get angry, and that’s when it got scary. Lipsky sees a child’s drawing displayed on the fridge: “Chickenhead Dave Wallace.”
(re: the drawing) Who’s the artist?

Hm? (Lipsky points.) Oh, my friend's daughter. Calls me Chickenhead, and I call her Chickenhead. Her latest salvo in the war. Laughing, Lipsky takes out his tape recorder and starts t set it up but stops. (Lipsky is a nervous laugher; he lau a_lot, not only where indicated.)  12.
You mind if I...?
Hey. Do what you’ve got to do. David watches uncomfortably. The ever-present tape record becomes a third character in this conversation.
Listen: Before we start putting stuff on tape, I gotta ask you something.
Okay...
I need to know that anything that I ask you five minutes later to not put in, you won’t put in.
Absolutely. He clicks off the recorder.
Given my level of fatigue and fuck-up quotient lately, it’s the only way I can see doin’ it and not going crazy.
I understand completely. Lipsky presses play.
Right back on, huh.
You agreed to the interview.

If I were there, maybe. The whole fuss has taken me out of school for the past two weeks and I’m gonna have to leave again tomorrow. We've got to get up at the crack of dawn to leave for the airport, by the way.
Oh, shit, do we really?
That's what you signed on for, man. You're welcome to stick around, write an article about my dogs. Might be more interesting, I promise you. David spits chewed tobacco into a Savarin can.
David and Lipsky walk to his classroom.
Do yourself a favor, don’t expect any fireworks in there...

I'm not any sort of authority on any sort of “program.” But from my very limited outside understanding, people who have been in it for a while: you could snort cocaine off the back of your hand and they’re okay. Lipsky is embarrassed for having been presumptuous.
You know what I would love to do?
What?
I would love to do a profile of one of you guys who’s doin’ a profile of me.
That is interesting... 15. Pause.  16.
Too po-mo and cute?
Maybe, for Rolling Stone.
But it would be interesting. (A beat.) I’m sorry.
What’s wrong?
It's just, you’re gonna go back to New York and sit at your desk and shape this thing however you want. And that to me is extremely disturbing.
Why is it disturbing?

‘Cause I would like to shape the impression of me that’s coming across. I can’t even tell if I like you yet ‘cause I’m too worried whether you like me. Before Lipsky can assure him, the waiter brings their sod

We’re fine, thanks. The waiter goes.
So what's this piece about? What does “Jann” want?
What’s it like being the most-talked about writer in the country. That sort of thing. That sounds so -- Lipsky seems embarrassed as soon as he says the words.  17.
How do you learn to do this stuff?
What.
Interviewing. Did you go to interviewing school?
No... I, uh... A beat. Lipsky feels a tad fraudulent to identify himself a writer to the man whose success and talent he envies.
I'm a writer.
Oh, yeah?
I mean I write fiction. Just published my first novel, as a matter of fact.
What’s it called?
The Art Fair? David shrugs. He’s never heard of it. Lipsky feels foolis for having brought it up.
And I, uh, had a collection published, a couple of years ago. Lipsky’s pumping leg betrays his anxiety. David notices.
You're a nervous guy, aren’t you?
No no I’m okay. How are you?
‘Cause I’m terrified.
Are you? I think it’s going to be a lot of fun.  18.
The food is decimated. David is loosening up.

The thing about this tour is... I would like to get laid out of ita couple of times, but... Like, people come up, they kinda slither up during readings or whatever. But it seems like, what I want is not to have to take any action.
Like...?
Like, I don’t want to have to say, “Would you like to come back to my hotel?” I want them to say, “I am coming back to the hotel. Where is your hotel?” Lipsky laughs.
I can’t stand to look like I’m actively trading on this sexually. Which of course I would be happy to do. In retrospect, it was lucky that I didn’t.
Why?
Basically, it just would have made me feel lonely.
Why lonely?
Because it wouldn’t have had anything to do with me, it would have just been...
Your fame?
Yeah. Whatever.  34 19.

You're famous. You can say that. Except... if they’re responding to your work, and the work is so personal... then trading on it is actually another way of meeting you, isn’t that right? A beat. David is impressed by Lipsky’s analysis.
That is so good.
Thank you.

This piece’ll really be good if it’s mostly you. Talk all you want, man, save me a whole lotta trouble. Lipsky laughs, sensing his stock has risen, relaxing more into the rhythm of their conversation.
David at the wheel, driving Lipsky’s rental. Lights from fast-food restaurant signs light up their faces. Tape running.
So this is what a real car feels like. The one I have is like riding a power lawn mower.
You think being handsome has anything to do with your success?
(incredulously) What?
You are photogenic... You look good in your author’s photo.
You'd have to come put me down if I even start thinking that way.
Thinking what way? About how books are sold?  35 20.
Like, “Do you want to do a Rolling Stone interview, do you want to do xX, do you want to do Y” worries me that what I’m doing right now is being a whore.
A whore? Why?
You know, cashing in somehow, or getting some little celebrity for myself. That will, from some bizarre set of misunderstandings, sell more copies of the book.
Right.
You can quote that. Preferably ina context where I don’t sound like a total dweeb. (A beat.) By the way, are they gonna send Annie Leibovitz to take pictures?
I’m not sure. Possibly.
I know: You’re a good-looking guy. We should have ‘em photograph you, and say you're me. Maybe I’1l finally end up getting laid. Lipsky laughs.
In the blue-white fluorescent light, David and Lipsky ad-lib while stocking up on six-packs of Diet Rite, chewi tobacco, Oreos, etc. At the cash register, Lipsky prepares to pay.
Let me.
You don’t have to pay for my shit.  36 37 21.
It’s not coming out of my pocket... I've got an expense account.
All right, if you insist... David goes back for more.
Riding through town, the Davids are eating candy like teenagers on a joyride.
If you ate this stuff all the time, what would be wrong with that?
Except for your teeth falling out and getting really fat?
Yeah, it doesn’t have any of the nourishment of real food, but it’s real pleasurable masticating and swallowing this stuff.
Like seductive commercial entertainment.
Exactly, and what saves us is that most commercial entertainment isn’t very good.
What about good seductive commercial entertainment - like Die Hard?
The first Die Hard? Great film.
Brilliant, right?
The best. EXT. DAVID’S HOUSE - 1996 - NIGHT 37 The car pulls up, parks. They get out with the spoils fro the 7-Eleven. Mid-discourse:  38 22.

So if the book’s about anything, it’s about the question of: Why am I watching all this shit? It’s not about the shit, it’s about me. Why am I doing it? And what’s so American about what I’m doing? We hear the dogs barking as David unlocks the door and th enter the house.
The dogs run out to do their thing. David puts away the s and snacks.
The minute I start talking about this stuff, it sounds, number one: very vague. And, two: really reductive.
I don’t think you’re being reductive or vague at all.

Because it’s like, I don’t have a diagnosis, a system of prescriptions. You know? Like, why are we - and by “we” I mean people like you and me: mostly white, upper middle class, obscenely well-educated, doing really interesting jobs, sitting in really expensive chairs, watching the best, most sophisticated electronic equipment money can buy - why do we feel empty and unhappy?
Kinda like Hamlet. With channel- surfing.

I’m not saying TV is bad or a waste of your time. Any more than, you know, Masturbation is bad or a waste of your time. It's a pleasurable way to spend a few minutes. But if you're doing it twenty times a day, if your primary sexual relationship is with your own hand, then there's something wrong.  Silence. 23.
At least with masturbation, some action has been performed, though, right?

All right, you could make me look like a real dick if you print this: Yes, you're performing muscular movements with your hand as you're jerking off. But what you're doing is running a movie in your head, and having a fantasy relationship with somebody who isn't real, in order to stimulate a purely neurological response. Look: as the Internet grows in the next ten, fifteen years, and virtual reality pornography becomes a reality, we're gonna have to develop some machinery, inside our guts, to help us turn off pure, unalloyed pleasure. Otherwise, I don’t know about you, but I’m gonna have to leave the planet.
(smiles uncertainly) Why?

Because the technology is just gonna get better and better. And it's gonna get easier and easier, and more and more convenient, and more and more pleasurable, to be alone with images on a screen, given to us by people who do not love us but want our money. Which is fine. In low doses. But if that's the basic main staple of your diet? You're gonna die. Ina meaningful way, you're going to die. Lipsky mulls over the gravity of what David has said. David breaks the portentous silence when he pops a of tobacco in his mouth.
Can I try that?
Be my guest. It takes some getting used to. Lipsky tries it and makes a horrible face. David laughs.  39 40 24.
You mind if I use your uh... Amused, David points the way to the bathroom.
I believe it’s unoccupied. Lipsky goes, leaving the tape running.

Lipsky spits the tobacco into the sink. He cups his hands under the running water and rinses his mouth. He looks at himself in the mirror and takes a deep, fortifying breath He stealthily opens the medicine cabinet and finds it sto with jars of vitamins, Stri-Dex pads and tubes of Topol, toothpaste for smokers. He jots down notes.
Lipsky returns, looks around. David is playing with his dogs.
Do you not have a TV?
I do not have a TV.
How come?

‘Cause if I had a TV, I'd watch it all the time. I don’t even know if I would watch it; it would be on all the time - my version of a fireplace. A source of warmth and light in the corner that I would occasionally get sucked into.
Did you watch a lot of T.V. when you were a kid?
Yeah. A lot. You?  25.
Me? Yeah, I did. I moved in with a woman who grew up without a television, and living with her, the first month was torture, and then I realized it was probably the best thing for me.
Did you guys stay together?
It’s complicated.
Why?

I was seeing this woman, then she moved to L.A. and we theoretically broke up. And I started seeing this other woman, but then I started seeing the first woman again - trying the bi- coastal thing - and the second... Well, let’s just say she hasn’t taken it very well.
It’s so much easier having dogs. You don’t get laid; but you also don’t get the feeling you’re hurting their feelings all the time. I emphasize: strictly platonic relationship with the dogs.
You're not dating anyone?
Seriously dating? No. I’m out of practice; I wouldn’t know what to say.
You want to have kids?
Yeah, I think someday I do; do you?
Yeah. Eventually. I think.  26.
Writing books is kinda like raising children, but you gotta be careful: you should take pride in the work but it’s bad to want that glory to reflect back on you.
You worry about having children? David seems far away; this is difficult for him. After a beat, he speaks, sounding vulnerable, which doesn’t go unnoticed by Lipsky.
I don’t know that I want to say anything more about it - okay?
(prepared to back off) That’s fine.
I mean, we can joke about getting laid on tour and stuff, but...
I just thought, it’d be nice to have someone to be sharing all this wonderful stuff with.
Yeah. I really have wished I was married, the last couple of weeks.
You have?

Yeah, because nobody quite gets it. Your friends who aren't in the writing biz are all just awed by your picture in Time, and your agent and editor are good people, but they have their own agendas. It’s fun talking to you about it, but you've got an agenda, too, and a set of interests that diverges from mine.
That’s true...  27.
There’s something nice about having somebody who kinda shared your life, and that you could allow yourself just to be happy and confused with.
Somebody you can call when you get back to the hotel.
Uh huh. (A beat.) So, why aren’t you married at thirty?
Why aren't you married at thirty-four?
You first.

Okay. Um... I think it's hard to cast that role .. to fill it when you know it's for thirty or forty years .. someone who, whatever mental landscape you're in, they're going to be in it too, you need someone who'll fit any landscape you can imagine.
Well, I can't put it as well as you did about the “mental landscapes,” I just know I'm hard to be around. David's “mental landscapes” reference: competitive, fawni mocking? Lipsky isn’t sure.
Why?

Because when I want to be by myself, like to work, I really want to be by myself. I think if you dedicate yourself to anything, one facet of that is that it makes you very very self-conscious. You end up using people. Wanting them around when you want them around, but then sending them away.
Comes with the territory, though, doesn’t it? Self-consciousness?  28.
There’s good self-consciousness. And then there’s this toxic, paralyzing, raped-by-psychic-Bedouins self- consciousness. Lipsky laughs.
(re: Alanis poster) Can you do me a favor? Can you tell me about that poster over there?
Alanis? I don’t know, I guess I'm susceptible like everybody else. Why?
She's pretty, alright...

Yeah, but in a very sloppy, very human way. That squeaky, orgasmic quality in her voice? Here’s what it is: A lot of women in magazines are pretty in a way that isn’t erotic because they don’t look like anybody you know.
True.
You can’t imagine them putting a quarter in a parking meter or eating a bologna sandwich. But her, I don't know, I just find her absolutely riveting.
How'd you get to know her, her music, I mean?
Listening to cheesy Bloomington radio, and “I Want to Tell You” came on.
(correcting him) “You Oughta Know.”
What?  29.
“I Want to Tell You” is the book 0.J. Simpson wrote.
Oh, right.
Wouldn't it be great if O.J. Simpson sang “You Oughta Know” and Alanis Morissette wrote a book about not killing two people? They laugh. Lipsky is pleased to make David laugh.
If somehow this whole fuss could get me even like a five-minute cup of tea with her...
Why don’t you put out feelers, see if she'd be willing to meet you?
You serious? I would never do that.
Why not?
I'd be too terrified. Why, you would do that?
If I were you? Why not?
